texts.definition: Commands that allow players to display purely emotional actions for their characters.
markups: <style="Definition">Commands that allow players to display purely emotional actions for their characters.</style>

Games lets player affect the game state through actions. However, in some games players want to be able to do other actions which while they do not affect the game state let them express emotions of their characters. <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> provides this possibility to players by letting them type what they want their characters to do in a command line prompt, and this is then presented to all other players that are nearby.

<style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> are used in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">MUDs</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Roleplaying Games</link></style>. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/MUD2">MUD2</link></style> they are evoked through the command "act" while [[DragonMud] uses ":", <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/BatMUD">BatMUD</link></style> both simply have the command "emote". For example, typing “: jumps around.” when playing as the PC named Bilbo would give nearby players the message “Bilbo jumps around.” Having graphical representations, <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Massively%20Multiplayer%20Online%20Games">Massively Multiplayer Online Roleplaying Games</link></style> are sometimes augmented with specific non-gameplay actions that avatars can enact; For example, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> lets players write freeform <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> by typing “/e” in the chat window but also allows players' avatars to perform dances if “/dance” is entered into the console window.

<style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> is an option for <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Command%20Line%20Systems">Command Line Systems</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illocutionary%20Interfaces">Illocutionary Interfaces</link></style> to help players provide purely emotional expressions for their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, i.e. <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> provide actions for players that do not affect the game state. This means that they are not necessary for games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Unmediated%20Social%20Interaction">Unmediated Social Interaction</link></style>.

Two basic forms of Emotes exist: freeform and specific. The first lets players type any kind of action to be presented to others while the other provides a list of specific actions that can be performed. The two can be combined but this makes most sense in Massively Multiplayer Online Roleplaying Games where Avatars can then enact these actions, this however requires creating specific animations and sounds for each allowed action.

Freeform <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> can be used to trick other players if they are truly freeform. For this reason, <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> may be limited in some form. An example of this is prefixing all <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> with the player's <style="Link"><link="handles">Handle</link></style> so that emoting "is looking happy." while playing as a <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> with the name (and <style="Link"><link="handles">Handle</link></style>) "Rollo" will let other players' see "Rollo is looking happy."
Allowing the use of <style="Link"><link="mules">Mules</link></style> in a game lets players automate the execution of <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style>.

Freeform <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> risks breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> as players can insert anything they wish into the game world.

<style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> is a way of modifying <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>. They provide players with the possibility of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Creative%20Control">Creative Control</link></style> - especially the freeform version - regarding their <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and by extension let them show that they are <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>. When used with <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, it can help create <style="Link"><link="emotional-attachment">Emotional Attachment</link></style> to these.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Social%20Interaction">Social Interaction</link></style> arise from using <style="CurrentLink">Emotes</style> since the expression of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters'</link></style> emotions by their players can be seen as a form of such interaction.
